subject: Philosophy
title: Lying to Save a Life
description: A micro-lesson that makes Lying to Save a Life usable.

hook.text: A killer asks if your friend is hiding inside. Should you lie?

buildup.text: Most people say obviously yes. But Kant said no â€” lying is always wrong, even here.

discovery.text: His reasoning: if lying became universal, no one would believe anyone and communication collapses.

twist.text: Critics say Kant's rigidity costs lives. Surely morality must be flexible enough to save your friend.

climax.text: This dilemma exposes the limits of rule-based ethics. Sometimes the right thing breaks a rule.

punchline.text: Rules that can't bend sometimes break people.

quiz.question: Why did Kant believe lying is always wrong?
options: If everyone lied, trust and communication would collapse
Because lies always cause more harm
